& I suppose for now, until such time that the light shines through, that will have to do.
Where is hope in this mess? It seems to be as tragic as "I can see the evil, so it hasn't won yet," & "I am still alive," & so I must work.
Yes, there are arguably worse moments in history. It should become easy to avoid, but instead it is perpetuated with fantastic consistency.
Consider: the miracle came long ago, & with such a promise among us, here we are. If you continue to hope or to fight, then you are a saint.
Waiting for the miracle, waiting for the world to change, waiting for God to come smite the devil; every phrase for anticipation in anguish.
This is the far side of Pentecost.
